citations.narrative:
* Vaccinations and medications listed on the program of veterinary care (PVC) are not being completely followed. The
program of veterinarian care establishes standards of care for the animals. A completed written program of veterinary
care is important for the care of the animals and ensures clear and accurate communication between the facility and the
attending veterinarian. Any changes in vaccinations or medications must be communicated with the attending
veterinarian. The licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented
in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 3/1/24.
* The following vaccination was given to one puppy born on 10/21/23 does not match what was listed on the Program of
Veterinary Care (PVC). The puppy was given a does of Bordetella (Intra Trac 3) on 11/18/23. The PVC calls for Bordetella
to be given at Five to Eight weeks of age as directed by the PVC.
* The PVC also says that Leptospirosis will be given at six weeks and a second vaccination would be given at eight weeks
of age. There was no documented prof that Leptospirosis had been given to this puppy as directed by the PVC.

* The number or percentage of 116 adult dogs that will be annually tested for Heartworm and Fecal float testing were not
recorded under the blood and intestinal parasites sections of the program of veterinary care (PVC).. Heartworm and fecal
float testing is done to ensure that there are no active internal parasites. Parasite testing according to the sampling plan
outlined by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary care is important for the health of the animals.
Recording the number or percentage of dogs that will be tested has to be listed in the blood parasite section and intestinal
parasite sections of the PVC. The licensee must record the sampling of adult dogs that will be tested for heartworm and
fecal float. Correct by 3/1/24.

* The preventive care section of the program of veterinary care (PVC) is incomplete for 116 dogs. It states "routine care"
under the clean and healthy eyes, ears, and skin sections. There is nothing outlined in all three sections what will be done
to provide care for the eyes, ears, and skin. Outlining what routine care will be provided is essential to the health and
wellbeing of the dog. When the program of vet care is missing information on how the licensee provides for the health and
well-being of all dogs on the premise it is not considered to be adequate veterinary care. The program of veterinarian care
establishes standards of care for the animals. A completed written program of veterinary care is important for the care of
the animals and ensures clear and accurate communication between the facility and the attending veterinarian. The
licensee must outline the preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly
trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. Correct by 3/1/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* Vaccinations and medications listed on the program of veterinary care (PVC) are not being completely followed. The 
program of veterinarian care establishes standards of care for the animals. A completed written program of veterinary 
care is important for the care of the animals and ensures clear and accurate communication between the facility and the 
attending veterinarian. Any changes in vaccinations or medications must be communicated with the attending 
veterinarian. The licensee must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented 
in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. Correct by 3/1/24.  
* The following vaccination was given to one puppy born on 10/21/23 does not match what was listed on the Program of 
Veterinary Care (PVC). The puppy was given a does of Bordetella (Intra Trac 3) on 11/18/23. The PVC calls for Bordetella 
to be given at Five to Eight weeks of age as directed by the PVC. 
* The PVC also says that Leptospirosis will be given at six weeks and a second vaccination would be given at eight weeks 
of age. There was no documented prof that Leptospirosis had been given to this puppy as directed by the PVC. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The number or percentage of 116 adult dogs that will be annually tested for Heartworm and Fecal float testing were not 
recorded under the blood and intestinal parasites sections of the program of veterinary care (PVC).. Heartworm and fecal 
float testing is done to ensure that there are no active internal parasites. Parasite testing according to the sampling plan 
outlined by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary care is important for the health of the animals. 
Recording the number or percentage of dogs that will be tested has to be listed in the blood parasite section and intestinal 
parasite sections of the PVC. The licensee must record the sampling of adult dogs that will be tested for heartworm and 
fecal float. Correct by 3/1/24. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
* The preventive care section of the program of veterinary care (PVC) is incomplete for 116 dogs. It states "routine care" 
under the clean and healthy eyes, ears, and skin sections. There is nothing outlined in all three sections what will be done 
to provide care for the eyes, ears, and skin. Outlining what routine care will be provided is essential to the health and 
wellbeing of the dog. When the program of vet care is missing information on how the licensee provides for the health and 
well-being of all dogs on the premise it is not considered to be adequate veterinary care. The program of veterinarian care

establishes standards of care for the animals. A completed written program of veterinary care is important for the care of 
the animals and ensures clear and accurate communication between the facility and the attending veterinarian. The 
licensee must outline the preventative care and treatment plans to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly 
trimmed nails, and clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. Correct by 3/1/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
